awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Manish Mehta at Oberlin College to study the formation of co-crystals - molecular crystals that involve two or more species which retain their molecular identity in the solid state. These structures are of great interest, as they provide a new way to control bulk properties of substances. For example, properties of pharmaceutical substances such as solubility and bioavailability may be altered by co-crystallizing the agent with an excipient. Co-crystals are often made using mechanochemistry (e.g., grinding the co-forming solids together), while others form spontaneously by simply mixing powders. Dr. Mehta seeks to enhance the understanding of these mechanisms using a combination of solid-state magnetic resonance, X-ray and neutron diffraction, and computational methods. The insight gleaned from these studies should help to inform the design and synthesis of co-crystalline materials with desired properties in the future. Participating undergraduate students receive hands-on experience in experimental design and execution and in drafting manuscripts for publication in peer-reviewed journals. Experiences such as these help to prepare interested undergraduates for graduate study in the STEM disciplines.

In this work, the PI and his undergraduate research team apply the tools of NMR crystallography to study the synthon structure of co-crystals and their formation using real time in situ solid-state NMR (ssNMR). They (1) investigate the kinetics of co-crystal formation; (2) create a detailed picture of the synthon structure (complementing single-crystal NMR data with neutron diffraction and ab initio calculations); and (3) examine single-crystal reaction dynamics using microscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction (scXRD). The NMR-based strategy provides kinetic data, including detection of any transient intermediates (liquid or solid) that might arise in the course of the solid-state reaction. A second goal is to investigate the hydrogen bond synthon structure in model co-crystal systems using neutron diffraction and single-crystal NMR (including assessment of proton shift tensors and their orientation in the crystal frame). Broadly construed, these studies are expected to help bridge the NMR crystallography and crystal engineering communities.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The field of crystal engineering seeks to understand and predict structures of crystalline molecular solids based on the non-covalent interaction between a few interacting structural units called synthons. In the course of this grant, we have applied a hybrid approach combining solid-state NMR and diffraction -- now recognized as NMR crystallography -- to study the structure and formation kinetics of a class of molecular crystals known as cocrystals. These crystals  -- which feature two or more different molecules in the unit cell -- have received fresh attention, especially in the pharma sector, where they have been shown to modulate properties of active pharmaceutical ingredients, such as solubility and bioavailability. The NMR Crystallography approach leverages the synergy between experimental chemical shifts (in solids), the shift-structure connection, and ab initio quantum chemical calculations. It reminds us that a full molecular picture consists of the nuclear coordinates and the accompanying electron distribution, one sensitive to the other, neither entirely devoid of the other. NMR and X-ray diffraction contain fundamentally complementary information; thus, they are linked in a deeply symmetrical way.

Intellectual Merit

Via a series of interconnected projects, we have investigated the spatiotemporal kinetics of cocrystal formation using a combination of solid-state NMR and diffraction. In one project, we investigated the NMR chemical shift tensor characteristics of cocrystals of caffeine and theophylline. In another, we detailed the dramatic catalytic effect of organic solvent vapors on the spontaneous formation of the caffeine-malonic acid cocrystal. Exposure to solvent vapors is able to shorten cocrystal formation from weeks to minutes. A third project surveyed the spontaneous formation of cocrystals when the powders are mixed and left to stand at ambient conditions, over a range of relative humidities. This surprising finding may have important implications for future cocrystal design. A fourth project invalidated two hypothesized mechanisms of mass transfer in spontaneous cocrystal formation using an innovative solid-state NMR experiment. While a negative result, it stands to have a significant impact on the community of researchers who investigate crystal formation. A fifth project established a stability hierarchy in the caffeine-diacid cocrystal system using competitive and displacive milling reactions. And, in a sixth project, we found NMR spectral evidence of a transient phase in the displacive formation of the caffeine-oxalic acid cocrystal. The structural details of the mechanistic intermediate remain a mystery. Our work has resulted in multiple publications in top-tier peer-reviewed journals.

Broader Impact

The work supported by this grant has had a broader impact on the crystal engineering community and on its undergraduate participants. In addition to the results generated (described in the Intellectual Merit section), our body of work continues to make a connection between the NMR crystallography and crystal engineering communities, where solid-state NMR is beginning to make a substantial impact on a field that is otherwise dominated by diffraction. The research under this grant was performed entirely by undergraduates. The research program, employing the latest techniques in solid-state NMR, diffraction, and computation, served as a rigorous training ground for its undergraduate participants. Many students who participated in the research supported by this grant have gone on to top graduate programs in biophysical and physical chemistry (such as MIT and Northwestern). They attest to the potency of the undergraduate research experience in their later success. A program such as ours serves as a powerful vehicle to nurture young scientific talent and contribute to the national brain trust.
